Hidden gem: Rep. @katieporteroc on Financial Services 

She consistently delivers incredible lines of questioning (and frequently adds a dash of humor).  https://twitter.com/RealBankReform/status/1103724736595546112¬†‚Ä¶

The DIRECTOR OF THE BUREAU MEANT TO #PROTECTCONSUMERS cannot even BALLPARK the APR of a short-term payday loan. So *how* does @CFPB Dir. Kraninger expect consumers to? 
‚Ä¶
replies: Let‚Äôs give it up for that calculator that slides into the frame around 0:48
Slides in, patiently waits, remains  unmolested. pic.twitter.com/udfA3aAl7C

Reclaiming my time. RECLAIMING MY TIME.

Jesus that was satisfying. Hope to see more of this when these people drone on avoiding questions.
I canvassed for her! She's great!
She's trained lawyer & professor with consumer financial protection experience

I dunno. These often feel like opps 2 put on a show and not abt asking substantive questions. Same for the Sec Nielsen questioning where it seemed some ppl just really desperately wanted her to say ‚Äòcage.‚Äô How valuable are these really to members of Congress? Genuinely curious.

The purpose is to put them on record & raise public awareness (in addition to any bills derived from said testimony on record)

Incredibly valuable when not a dog & pony show. This is what happens when you send people to gov‚Äôt who actually want to govern in the people‚Äôs interest

This line of questioning, trying to get someone to say the APR, do you think then that that type of viral (if it is) moment is as valuable or more valuable than a concise deconstruction of the policies enacted by the person called up to testify.

Absolutely. If she hadn‚Äôt done that, the clip would not be noteworthy because media (social, traditional, etc) simply doesn‚Äôt react to policy wonk discussions. Do I wish that weren‚Äôt true? Mostly.

But are we now talking about integrity as Congresspeople & predatory lending? Yes.

Appreciate you engaging w/ me as opposed to dunking on me btw! I‚Äôm not sure tho, do we remember whom Maxine Waters was reclaiming her time from or do we just think she is a legend and have it emblazoned on T-shirts. AOC‚Äôs Qs to Cohen felt substantive nd shareable on social.

Taking a (perhaps naive) less cynical view, I would posit that political power & influence is abt winning hearts & minds. And especially for MOC who don‚Äôt take Corp/special interest $, it‚Äôs *critical* to demonstrate their allegiance to the people, so the people support them. 1/

Grassroots fundraising for MOC is tough if districts aren‚Äôt as wealthy, so national name recognition is a boon. We also have a recall bias...it may very well be that there are 10x more clips of her being wonky that you just haven‚Äôt seen...which sort of proves the point? 2/2

Always happy to engage in honest, civil discourse. It exists on Twitter! ...though it‚Äôs rare =/

I haven't had to calculate a weird rate like this before, but I *think* it's ~31.2% APR?

Someone please correct my math if I'm wrong; not 100% sure I modeled this right. pic.twitter.com/XIqgugvSmg

Not even close. It costs $40 (orig fee is part of APR calculation) to borrow $200 for 2 weeks, which is 20% of the loan amount. So that‚Äôs 10% for 1 week, or 520% for 52 weeks. The APR as defined by the very department this chump is supposed to be in charge of is 520%.

I'm not sure about your math there

Even if the orig fee is included in the APR cost, it's only added once. The 10% is supposed to be for 2 weeks, which would mean it's closer to 260% APR (10% x 26 bi-weeks), wouldn't it?

Your calc is applying the orig fee repeatedly

the original charge & the interest is a $40 finance charge for a $200 loan so for one year it works out to 40/200=.2*365=73 then that is divided by the original loan time of 14 days 73/14=5.21 made into a % that‚Äôs 521%. APR includes that fee to calc the total
It's official. 521% is absolutely correct. I get *some* credit (no pun intended) for doing it on the fly in my head...  https://twitter.com/RepKatiePorter/status/1105302493901320192?s=20¬†‚Ä¶
